commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2960 - Create WAKE functional tests

Test suite that verifies output of AT!WAKEPINSET and AT!SMSWAKE

Resolves: SWIMDM-2960
Change-Id: Ib0bc49eb4274c50ab7b41f3777a9e50d2ade26a4
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2960 - Create WAKE functional tests

comments.message: Really great addition to our testing. It has already discovered some potential security issues (odd behaviour with slatoi and its overflow mechanism). I've added comments below to align us with how the integration team is implementing these type of tests. We should align it with their patterns, even if our previous tests do not follow that pattern.
This has to be AT!SMSWAKE (include AT and the specificer "!" in this case). Same for all the instances accross this patchset.

We should adopt the integration's team's method of doing these type of verification. 

In the integration/letp/sanity/results folder there are .yaml files with exepcted results of AT commands. The default.yaml is the "master" file that gets overlayed by additional product files like EM.yaml, RC, WP etc. Since this is a platform test, the default.yaml file should be used. 

In there you can add an entry: 

AT!SMSWAKE=?:
     - '!SMSWAKE:'
     - '  0,xx -  Disable SMS WAKE functionality.'
     - '  1,xx -  Enable SMS WAKE functionality.
     - '  xx - 32-bit hex value for wakeMask, not applicable when WAKE functionality disabled.'
     - 'OK'

Then the test can be simplified. 


@skipif_atcmd_disabled("AT!SMSWAKE")
@at_unlock_level_2
def QTI_INT_AT_SMSWAKE_0000(target, helpers, non_network_tests_setup_teardown):
  results = non_network_tests_setup_teardown

  ...

  target.run_at_cmd("AT!SMSWAKE=?", 1, results["AT!SMSWAKE=?"])

This can also be done using the results tables. 

Add this in default.yaml

AT!SMSWAKE?:
   - '!SMSWAKE:"
   - 'Enabled|Disabled'
   - '[0-9A-F]{8}'
   - OK

Although I am not 100% on the regular expression format for the value '[0-9A-F]{8}'. Might have to experiment a bit to figure it out fully. 

Then this code can simply become

target.run_at_cmd("AT!SMSWAKE?", 1, results['AT!SMSWAKE?'])

This pattern should be repeated on all the simple output verification tests.
The brackets are not needed. Same for each entry in this list.
Can you add a space before and after?

Thanks Yusuf for making the changes. It is looking better and better. 

Another round of comments from me. This time main focus is updating to use assert instead of manually raising Exceptions. 

It is getting close.
This should be updated to target.run_at_cmd("AT!SMSWAKE?", 1, results["AT!SMSWAKE?"]), unless it was not working due to the regular expression in the results file?

please use the assert statement. 


  assert rsp[2] == "Enabled", "SMSWAKE was not set to Enabled successfully"

or alternatively (my preference), 

  assert "Enabled" in rsp, "SMSWAKE was not set to Enabled successfully"

If using the alternative, then rsp does not need to be split into a list. Can remove the ".split('\r\n')"

should be assert as well, and possibly get show the response in the error message

assert all(c in string.hexdigits for c in rsp[3]), "Current width contains non-hex char - %s" % (rsp[3])

Should be: 

  assert "Disabled" in rsp, "SMSWAKE was not set to Disabled successfully"

I think what you had before was more accurate. We actually need to check that test_input is within the query of ATSMSWAKE. I would use the previous code, but instead of the Exception, use the assert. 

  rsp = target.run_at_cmd("AT!SMSWAKE?", 1, [r"OK"])
  assert test_input in rsp, "Setting SMSWAKE with hex value failed!"

Can you update this to be just

  assert rsp_old == rsp_new, "Original hex width value overwritten by invalid input!"

This way pytest will display the difference of the two if there are differences.
please add a space before nad after

Shouldn't this be a failure? or does swilog.error cause the test to fail? 

I think using the assert is still better. 

  rsp = target.run_at_cmd("AT!SMSWAKEWIDTH?", 1, [r"OK"])
  assert good_value in rsp, "width not set successfully!"

This is as what I suggested, but looking at the results you posted on JIRA, it makes a convoluted error message, as run_at_cmd times out waiting for "ERROR". Can you update it as below to make it cleaner error message?

  
  resp = target.run_at_cmd("AT!SMSWAKEWIDTH="+bad_value, 1, [r"OK|ERROR"])
  assert "ERROR" in resp, "ERROR is expected, instead returned OK"

Should also update to assert. 

  assert "State:     1" in rsp, "bsgpio state incorrect!"

Same for the line 39-40.

One followup comment. 

It would also be great if we can add some more negative test cases. For example query or trying to set a value when the AT Unlock is level 1 (locked). This would improve the coverage, and set an example of how to develop complete coverage test cases for future AT commands.
This should be its own test. Setting a value when disabling SMSWAKE.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2895 - Use the decorators for enforcing target AT unlock level

Using the at_unlock_level_<n> decorators to ensure tests are ran with
the requires AT unlock level. All thests that requires AT unlock level 3
are ran with at_unlock_level_3. The flog_target fixture also requires
its setup and teardown code to be ran with at_unlock_level_3, this
ensures both the setup and teardown will have the device unlocked and
access to AT!FLOG=2 command.

Adding some minor tests to the lock level of certain commands. For
example AT!FLOG? is only callable when the device is in unlock level 2
or level 3, and must return error when device is in lock level 1.
Similar test is done for ADC and BSGPIO

Change-Id: I7145baa364d3cf1684cf0f4876cfb7ebf71b8cb2
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2895 - Use the decorators for enforcing target AT unlock level

SWIMDM-2414 - Add LeTP test for test SIM select

Add CP LeTP test for test SIM select (AT+KSIMSEL=50) along with
associated test campaign and readme. This test contains a
feature enablement check which will be removed once AT
command stock is available from the package framework.

Related: SWIMDM-2182
Resolves: SWIMDM-2414
Change-Id: Iccbb04a90f837e3dbf77f85c368a5e1364cb53e2
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2414 - Add LeTP test for test SIM select

comments.message:
Looks good. 
I am only wondering if there is anything else from test plan in SWIMDM-2182 that can be added to this test (without actually testing attach to the callbox). Seems that we tested a bit more in that ticket.

I talked to Mohit about this at the end of last week and unfortunately the other portion of what was tested in SWIMDM-2182 is not supported across the platforms that this test could run on. Until we start getting the .json build reports with enabled features I feel like it might be better to keep these tests as "universal" as possible.
I seem to remember that this feature is not supported on WP76.
Removed this after Stoyans comment in our meeting last week.
Added test evidence in SWIMDM-2414 as well as temporary feature enablement checking.
Updated test documentation and style to be in line with SWIMDM-2239
Some minor comments and a discussion point on a corner case that the test case will not catch.
Thanks for the review Stoyan, added responses inline and a couple of potential solutions for addressing the edge case.

This test case compares that the IMSI is switched, not necessary that it is using a TEST SIM. if AT+KSIMSEL=50 ends up switching to the embedded SIM due to some bug, then the test will still pass. Its an unlikely scenario but shows there is a gap in this test case. Any other way we can identify that it is switch to the test SIM?

This is definitively a good point. I am not sure if there is a way we can 100% verify that the active SIM IMSI is for the TEST SIM (maybe Mohit would be able to comment on this) however something we can do practically is test the IMSI response from every category of AT+KSIMSEL response making sure all responses are unique.

The only downside to this would be that it brings this test a bit out of scope. In this case though, it might be warranted.

Another way we could more strongly verify that the IMSI is from the TEST SIM is to use the AT+SASIMINFO? response which lists the IMSI for both the physical and eSIM. I feel this approach would bring the test even more out of scope as many modules do not have this command enabled.

I think checking TEST IMSI (which is missing currently) via AT+CIMI on top of AT+KSIMSEL? shall suffice to prove that test imsi is in use due to virtue of +KSIMSEL=50 and not a case when an actual TEST SIM is inserted in the module.

Hi Mohit, thank you for the comment. The test already gets the TEST IMSI using AT+CIMI on top of AT+KSIMSEL? (see line 72) and makes sure that it has switched from the physical SIM IMSI. I don't know if you know of any other checks you think we should do with the TEST IMSI?

Hi Emery, As discussed offline, checking new IMSI != old IMSI is not sufficient to prove that module is using emulated TEST SIM. TEST IMSI used in this feature is a static value programmed by the firmware (http://cgit-legato/sierra-mdm.git/tree/uicc/src/uicctestsim.c#n173) and the module is always expected to come up with IMSI (001010123456789) written in the EFS file. 

So I think explicitly checking the test IMSI value on top of +KSIMSEL? response shall suffice to mark this as PASS. A false positive in this case anyway mean that system is in some unreliable state.
Should check that +KSIMSEL is actually set to 0 before the reset and fail the test if not.
Should check that +KSIMSEL: 50 is returned on a query.
Whats the purpose of the sleeps, and why are the values different? 5 seconds on line 53 and 10 seconds here.

While testing I noticed that different modules take a different amount of time for the new SIM IMSI to be updated after the reset. These values more or less came experimentally however after some more testing I feel its best to just increase the delay time slightly for all occurrences.

Let update to just a standard assert. 

  assert new_IMSI == old_IMSI, "IMSI did not switch to test SIM"
Thanks for picking this up Yusuf. I've added some comments below, and one that I overlooked at first but it started bugging me looking at the code more (see comment about space after #).
Lets remove these two lines. If the test is not skipped then it is enabled :)

Sorry for making you make these changes, but can you add a space after each #? 

    # Make sure test SIM not already active

etc. Makes it more readable.
LGTM. Just one request for a last sanity test run as its been a while since this was ran. Can you run it and update the JIRA results before I merge it?
As discussed offline the current JIRA results are still valid.

SWIMDM-2751 - Update AT!FLOG response formatting and add entry length test

Removed check for string "DONE" in AT!FLOG read response and unblocked existing
tests from running on WP76/RC76 modules.

Added new test case to test behaviour when large strings are written and
read out of FLOG.

Resolves: SWIMDM-2751
Change-Id: I78a15a27ee34287152b18d66164784704c1dddfb
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2751 - Update AT!FLOG response formatting and add entry length test

comments.message: Should move them as part of the test method, I don't see a reason for them to be global.

Technically it should be the same behaviour no matter the class, however the test should run for class Long and class Med. This is very easy to do with pytest's parametrize decorator

  @skipif_atcmd_disabled("AT!FLOG")
  @pytest.mark.parametrize("log_class", [0, 1])
  def QTI_INT_ATFLOG_0004(target, non_network_tests_setup_teardown, helpers, read_config, log_class):

Then pytest will actually generate two versions of this test. One for class 0 and one for class 1. The log_class can be used to formulate the actual AT command. 

  'AT!FLOG=0,%s,%s' % (log_class, test_msg_under)

Same for line 69. 

In fact we can expand on this and parametrize the message too. It simplifies the test and reduces the duplication. 

  @skipif_atcmd_disabled("AT!FLOG")
  @pytest.mark.parametrize("log_class", [0, 1])
  @pytest.mark.parametrize("message_len", [254, 255, 256])
  def QTI_INT_ATFLOG_0004(target, non_network_tests_setup_teardown, helpers, read_config,   log_class, message_len):
     print("\n------------ Test Case Start ------------\n")
     ...
     message = "X" * message_len 
     'AT!FLOG=0,%s,%s' % (log_class, message)
     target.run_at_cmd(cmd, 1, [r"OK"])
     # Read flog entries
     flog_rsp = target.run_at_cmd("AT!FLOG?", 300, [r"OK"])
     # Process flog response
     long, med = proc_flog_rsp(flog_rsp, helpers, read_config, "ALL", fw_str)
     # Fail in the case that there are not two entries for long category
     assert len(long) == 2, "Incorrect number of category long messages returned"
     assert len(med) == 1, "Incorrect number of category medium messages returned"
     # Verify that the 254 char string has been printed with no modifications
     assert long[0] == log_created_str, "Long category missing file header"
     assert long[1] == message, "Incorrect long category message returned"
     assert med[0] == log_created_str, "Med category missing file header"
     # Clear recent flog entries
     target.run_at_cmd("AT!FLOG=2", 1, [r"OK"]

     print("\n------------ Test Case End ------------\n")

Since the 255 and 256 messages would cause truncation we can add an additional assert based on the "message_len" value. Pytest will automatically generated and run 6 test cases based on the log_class and message_len parametrization.

I wasn't aware of this "parameterize" decorator before, I agree that it is good to test on both message classes, I have also updated another existing test to use this convention (increase our test coverage).
Do we need to update the error messages here and on line 79 and 81?

Nit picking here for the sake of improvement. This method should really be called on a teardown otherwise if any of the asserts hit or test fails we never clean-up the flog.

If this was a Test Class it would be trivial to add it as a teardown_method, however since LeTP and the FW Integration FW mandate only test methods then we need to use pytest's fixtures. You can create the new fixture that uses an yield vs a return. Anything before the yield is executed at setup time and after the yield at teardown. 

  @pytest.fixture
  def flog_target(target)
     # maybe do AT!FLOG=2 as a setup as well?
     # target.run_at_cmd("AT!FLOG=2", 1, [r"OK"])

     yield target
     # anything after the yield is only called on teardown
     target.run_at_cmd("AT!FLOG=2", 1, [r"OK"])

then rather than using the "target" fixture in the test code the new "flog_target" fixture should be used. 

This is not that critical for the FLOG case but unless we do correct cleanup procedures we risk interfering with other test cases if this one fails. The above code is how I would do it. Up to you if you want to make this change. If you decide to do it then I think it would be a good precedence on how to properly cleanup.

Good point on the test cleanup. In theory this should not be a problem because every test actually clears the flog before execution, however best practices dictate we should always clean-up after just in case.

After taking another look, it seems that we have similar test setup practices for all the flog tests (clear, get fw string). It makes sense to throw those into the setup/teardown routine as well.
Thanks for updating the code Emery! I've added two more comments. The second comment is up to you if you want to attempt it. Otherwise it looks good!

Thanks again for making this improvement. One last comment from me, sorry about that! 

Can you also do a quick sanity test run, if you haven't done so already.

Hi Stoyan, I updated the ticket to have the latest logs for the RC76 testing using locally built FW. I haven't been able to run the other ones due to the CI build instabilities this week.

I can build and run the other platforms locally with this if required or re-trigger the CI if desired, although the test output should be the same.
Thanks, that RC76 run is fine. No need to do others.
Since this is now part of the teardown we can remove it.
Thanks for pointing that out, should be removed on all tests.
KW errors were not related to this repository, or this topic.  Overriding the -2 vote.

comments.message: Thanks Stoyan, should all be addressed inline.

Please use "#" for inline comments. The doc-style string comment should only be used for function header/file documentation. All other code related comments should be #, even if multiple line comments. 

  # Comment 2
  # Next line

Please update all the files to use # for comments vs """. Only use """ for doc-strings (function header, file header etc.)

can be done with 

  for filename in log_filenames:
     ...
  else
     pytest.fail("AT!FMR response contains invalid file name")

Its better to iterate the list directly than using an index.

Iterating the list directly is preferred, makes it more readable too

  for entry in entries

Looks good to me and the test plan is well documented and seems thorough for the FLOG component.

My only concern is about where was this tested. Can it be tried on WP targets? It will be nice to try it on SDX65 too - I can help here if needed.

Hi Dejan, this test was developed on the WP77 platform as seen in Jira test evidence. On RC76/WP76 the AT!FLOG command is currently broken.

Can we try these FLOG tests on some other well established platforms like WP76/WP77?

These flog tests have all been tested on WP77 as seen on the Jira test evidence.

comments.message:
Can you also add the related SIMSA tickets? For example, SIMSA development was done in SWIMDM-2064, so you can add:

Related: SWIMDM-2064

I am not sure where your test plan for the SIMSA feature is coming from? Can you add that ticket to the related list too?

Just wondering,  which module is used for these CP tests?  Will this test case be used for all modules ?  We have discussed the common test script development strategic before and agree to use yaml file to specify the various AT response for various modules, and test script will get the expected response based on the yaml file.  I would suggest to keep this  strategic so that the test script can be shared
Looks good. Some simple comments and questions are added to the review.
Right now this test is primarily for WP77 (only enabled on this platform) but adding the response to the yaml file will be better for once this feature is available outside CP.
I think we have similar function on integration test framework. Please check with Joey
We usually try not to have these trailing whitespaces in all of the sierra created files.
Hi Emery, added some high level comments.

Is this based on manual observation? 8 seconds seems on a higher side to me as it should be available within 3-4 seconds ideally. Instead of hard wait, should we poll for few times before giving up after max attempts?
This was based on manual observation, however the idea of polling several times seems more robust.

Better to use +KSIMSEL for all +KSIMSEL operations.

For reference, https://confluence.sierrawireless.com/display/CP/SIM+Switching+Agent+User+Guide mentions only +KSIMSEL so better to use it exclusively for all SIMSA testing.

Thanks Mohit, I added this part following the test plan from https://confluence.sierrawireless.com/display/CP/SIM+Switching+Agent+Test+Plan+and+Use+Cases. I do agree that keeping the scope of each of these tests smaller is probably much better.
LGTM, can you please remind why testing was done on WP77 and NOT on WP76 where SIMSA is natively enabled!

I think this was mostly because I did not have a working WP76 module until recently (was missing RF cal). If you would prefer, I can run the tests again on WP76 although I imagine the behaviour would be similar.
Thanks for addressing my comments. LGTM.
Just a couple minor comments added in-line.

I think it would be good to add a little more detail to what we're doing.  Could we document what tests are available and what behaviour they confirm?

We could also add a few comments to indicate that this test directory is valid for:
1. AT+KSIMSEL=? reply includes option '40' for SIMSA.
2. SIERRA_ENABLE_SIMSA is enabled in the package configuration for the module.

I am not sure what level of detail would be good here as all of our other tests have a similar one line readme right now. It might also be worth to go back to expand upon these a little bit. The confluence links I have included contain well written documentation as far as exact steps of the test etc, but if preferred, I can move this information to the local readme.
In terms of test scope, this LGTM. As discussed offline, this test could be repeated on WP76 when autoconfigure work in flight gets merged.
Some comments below. Overall it looks good, my comments are mainly to improve readability and future maintainability.
Is an exception raised if AT+ICCID does not return OK? This could happen if there is no SIM, or a SIM error. The return of these commands would be a "+CME ERROR: SIM failure" for example.

If the response does not contain "OK", an exception will be raised and the test case will fail. This is built into the run_at_cmd method. All tests from both CP and FWINT are currently using this method, however I think eventually there might be better ways of doing this.
nit: should just be "return imsi_str, iccid_str" No need to create a list
Is there a need for the 5 retries on the AT command?
Made this into a singular check
Can you describe what "sim" is expected to be? Seems like its a list that stores all the SIM information? Is it just the response lines?
"sim" is just the set of AT+SASIMINFO? response lines for a given SIM (sim_0. sim_1). Updated in documentation
This error message should be expanded, perhaps a smarter way of extracting the fields is needed. If any of them are missing the failure message should be clear enough to know what was missing.

Thinking about this again, this check is completely unnecessary as the YAML response framework would have already failed the test if any response fields are missing (It will also show which fields are missing). This check has now been removed.

It would make it more readable if we actually return a dictionary or a named tuple. Namedtuple might be a good fit for here. That way the checks on line 65 would be more readable, i.e esim_fields.iccid == soft_iccid and esim_fields.imsi == soft_imsi for example. 

https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.html#collections.namedtuple

Is there a reason the assert function is used rather than the assert keyword? 

assert esim_fields[0] == soft_iccid and esim_fields[1] == soft_imsi, 
       "SASIMINFO mismatch from current AT reponses" 

Should do the trick in standard pytest. Without the brackets is more readable
This was just to be in line with the style of the other CP tests. I agree that the keyword is more readable and have changed the code to match
This is not needed. The assert will fail if either or re.search() functions return None.
please add a comment for the function. It would be helpful to also describe what target, helpers and val are supposed to be. This would be good to have for all functions here.

This is a more of pedantic comment, but we should still validate, especially if we expect "+KSIMSEL: 40" vs for example "+KSIMSEL:     40". 

On the other hand if we are only interested in the "40" value, rather than the format for everything else then we should either be doing a regular expression and extracting the 40, or some other way to extract and check against 40.
Looking back at documentation it should be ok just to do a regex search for the 40. Code changed to match.

This is more of a framework question, but why do we have to specify the AT command twice? One to run it, and again to lookup the results in dictionary? I guess what is this "results" dictionary that is being set on line 128.

The run_at_cmd method takes parameters: AT command, timeout, expected response. Since we are using the response dictionary generated from the YAML lookup files, we need to specify this command twice. I would like to update this in the framework to reduce repetition however this change can probably be rolled in with the AT command stock changes with the pkg framework updates.
We are getting the response lines 1 to 7, and 7 to 14 for sim_0 and sim_1 information?
Yes, both sims are returned in one response by the command (one after the other). You can see the formatting here: https://confluence.sierrawireless.com/display/CP/SIM+Switching+Agent+User+Guide

Thanks for addressing my comments. Some minor follow-up.

I wonder if we can demonstrate a failure as a proof that this test case will catch issues. Perhaps we can work-off line to spoof a build that will cause a failure and see if the test case catches it.

Thanks for the reviews Stoyan, we can definitely try a build with an altered response to verify the test case.

I also tried running this test on an older WP76 which for some reason is not able to read status out of its eSIM and the test case failed as expected. Maybe we can try and create a build that behaves similar to this?

Thanks for adding the Params. Can you consolidate the the two comments into a single one. 
  """
  Function for collecting IMSI and ICCID of active SIMS

  Params: target                     Target module object for running test
          helpers                    Class contains helpful AT cmd parsing functions
  """

Same of the other comment blocks below.
Does this apply to the retry mechanism or this whole function?
This would apply for the whole function. Once support for the package framework updates is added, this function would not be needed.

Thanks Stoyan for the review, comments address below.

Patch Set 12:

Posting some high level points for discussion from a architecture perspective 
- I strongly feel all test cases should have setUp() (to do any test specific configurations) and tearDown() (To revert back to default configuration) sections even if it just contains a print() statement to start with. In fact stretching this further, it would be good add-on if framework mandates this 'requirement'
- I think we should try to leverage Object oriented principles to start with e.g. A Base 'platform' class which will carry common attributes/methods. One of the possible use cases would be to list commands supported on all platforms e.g. AT!GSTATUS. Then a product specific class e.g. WP76xx which will inherit from 'platform' and finally variant classes which will be inherited from it's corresponding product class and will contain variant specific attributes.

Then a product specific class e.g. WP76xx which will inherit from 'platform' and finally variant classes which will be inherited from it's corresponding product class and will contain variant specific attributes.

These are good suggestions, thanks.

- Added example of setup and teardown fixture. Setup and teardown are possible with fixtures like in FWINT, but I'm not able to find a way to enforce the existence of test-specific setup and teardown functions.

- LeTP already does some variation of this, but it's not very fleshed out. I think that if we are to have a system like this then it would be better to implement upstream (in LeTP). cp_tests is meant to be lightweight so that we do not have to spend lots of time to maintain things other than our tests.

comments.message: General comment - all files should have a basic header indicating Copyright 2020 for Sierra Wireless. Also would be good to have one or two lines describing the purpose of the file.
Done. LeTP has a __copyright__ variable line so that is also used here.
Wonder if we should structure our tests by package. For example, this AT command lives in BS/HW. Does it make sense to have a similar directory structure for the tests?

That's a good idea for organization and for simplifying the test campaign json files. Done. There may be some tests in the future that don't fit neatly into this structure, but those can be put into another folder later on.

all coding should follow a general python coding standard,e.g.
"Currrent Time:",
"Temperature",
......

not sure why we will use assert

In general, you can use target.run_at_cmd() to verify multiple field directly.  If any field is unmatched, it will assert automatically.

e.g. target.run_at_cmd('AT!GSTATUS?', 1,
            [r'Current Time:*Temperature:*',
             r'Modem Mitigate Level:*ModemProc Mitigate Level:*',
             ...........
             ]
Done. Refactored places where it makes sense to match with run_at_cmd. There are still some situations where parsing the output is needed.
suggest we remove rc51. We can add it later if we commercialize it.
If this file is supposed to be generic (like the wp76xx.xml and wp77xx.xml) then let's be consistent and name this file em91xx.xml.

Done. The generic name must stay the same however.

The reason for this is because LeTP-internal has classes for those modules named EM91, RC76, etc. , and LeTP uses the generic name as the name of the class to use.
http://cgit-legato/Legato/LeTP-internal.git/tree/internal_lib/modules_threadx.py#n209

Public LeTP uses WP76xx, WP77xx, etc.
http://cgit-legato/Legato/LeTP.git/tree/framework/module/pytest_plugin/lib/modules_linux.py#n777

Code to determine this: http://cgit-legato/Legato/LeTP.git/tree/framework/module/pytest_plugin/lib/modules.py#n60

FWINT and Legato-qa (and this repo too) have generic name defined twice in different places. Once in the specific config to be able to find the general config file with the same name in target.xml, and again in the general config without the "xx" for some modules so LeTP can find the right class.

How is this file different from em91 or em9190?
Note there is no EM9192 product.

This is to handle the case if a user defines the module name in target.xml to be the exact model instead of the generic model family, ex. EM9190 instead of EM91xx.

Renamed to EM9191.
The generic name is the module family, so this should be wp76xx in this case.

I suppose this is taken from a different project. However, let me just mention that this test case asserts GMI command response relative to the ATI command response. So, if both ATI and GMI commands return wrong data, this test will not be able to pick it up. It will be better to have an 'absolute' test against the expected values.
This is just a comment, and I am not sure if it is worth extending this now.

It's true that the test is just comparing output from different AT commands which are likely using the same underlying source, but in general there is no easy way to determine what is the "correct and expected" data since these tests are meant to be run independently of the build.

In this case I suppose the expected data would just be "Sierra Wireless, Incorporated" for all of our products.
Do we want to add an assert that the reboot time is less than some value (that we know is reasonable)?

This test is a placeholder for now, it requires some changes to LeTP or new reboot handling with AT commands to be reliable. It's more of a demo that it is possible to test other things besides AT commands with LeTP, but right now it is just skipped by default.

Once this test is ready then I can add thresholds for the reboot time.
Could use AT+KGSN=4 instead. It has the truncated FSN and is the customer-facing command.

Some WP76 variants have MCU and some do not, so this is tough to test
Added checking of MCU status via AT!MCUINFO on WP products only to determine valid ADC channels.
Question - would it be easier to put things like GPIO min/max in this file (or em91.xml) or leave it in test_at_bsgpio.py? A question of centralized vs distributed information.

Good point on the location of info that is specific to each module. There is a LeTP config option to specify additional per-test .xml files. I will use that feature as a demo of how it works and to make the GPIO min/max numbers available for other tests.

In the future I think that info that is most closely related to a single test but may also be used by other tests to reduce duplication will follow this format.

It would be nice to document each function, even with a brief comment describing its intention. "Setups up fixture for all possible ADC channels per different module". Its also generally good to have some documentation in the code. Please apply this comment to all functions in the review.
Perhaps down the line the AT IFS can be used to generate the expected names, or have a configure file. This way any platform differences are handled outside of the test code.
Would a crash not cause a failure? If so it is better to let it run and mark test as expected failure.
In this case a module crash and reboot will case subsequent tests to fail because the AT port will be inaccessible for a period of time. Changed to mark test case as xfail instead of skipping.
Fixed. This was due to bug in LeTP (LETP-451). That has since been fixed in LeTP 1.9.1 and cp_tests.xml manifest has been updated to use that version, so this workaround is no longer needed.

Just a nitpick really. Sometimes it is helpful to specify the failure reason 

assert int(re.search(r"Number:    *(\d+)", rsp).group(1)) == i, "Wrong GPIO number" 

etc.
I assume this would raise an exception and fail the test if AT!BSGPIO? returns OK? Can we also add a test for invalid query string? AT!BSGPIO?"1" for example or AT!BSGPIO?SOMESTRING.

Done. Yes, it will fail the test if ERROR is not found in the AT command response.

In general though it's not possible to test every scenario, so these tests will be limited to testing only the most likely points of failure or testing code that is currently worked on by a developer. There may be demand in the future for a system to rigorously test AT commands based on the IFS as you have mentioned in another comment.
If a device is already unlocked level 3, does it get restored to locked at the end of each test?
Added functionality to return device to locked status after end of each test.

Perhaps a fixture that auto locks is also good. 

@pytest.fixture()
def unlock_lvl_3(target):
    yield Helpers.unlock_lvl_3(target)
    Helpers.lock_target(target)
    time.sleep(5) # bypass the back-off timers

This way the device is locked at the end of any test function that has used the unlock_lvl_3 fixture. This might improve the handling of tests that have different outputs based on the unlock status of the device. What do you think?

Initially the fixture approach was used but the problem with fixtures is that they must be run before testing starts. So there is no flexibility in where in the test the module will be unlocked. But the idea to only lock the module if it has been unlocked is good, this can be implemented in the future.

The time.sleep(5) line is also less than ideal since this adds a large delay between each test. The best solution would be an AT command to lock the target again without invoking the back off timer. This can be done with AT!UNLOCK in atlock.c but not in atsp.c which is what the WP modules use.

> Initially the fixture approach was used but the problem with fixtures is that they must be run before testing starts. So there is no flexibility in where in the test the module will be unlocked. But the idea to only lock the module if it has been unlocked is good, this can be implemented in the future.

That's a good point on the fixture. But touching on Mohit's point, we need a framework to ensure each test module gets the device from a known state. A module scope fixture to force an unlocked device to be locked might be the better approach. We let module's handle their own internal device state, but when that module is done, the framework resets device back to a known state for next module. Otherwise we might end up with flakey tests that only pass/fail if ran before/after certain tests. Can we have a module_teardown module-scope fixture that gets executed at the end of each module (similar to setup_teardown being autouse but at module-scope)? If so then we can check the unlock status, "at!unlock?" , "at!entercnd?" before locking the device at the end of the module. Other device states might have to be reset, or perhaps do a general NV restore, at a risk of flash wear, but at least we are guaranteeing each test_module.py gets the device from a known state.
I am not sure what python coding standard we are following, but this does not fit well with pep8. The closing bracket should be on line 68.

This is the style that the Black formatter uses. To reduce the amount of comments related to style I'm in favour of there being an informal rule similar to "If new code has been processed by a popular style formatter such as Black or yapf then the format will stand."

However, I don't think having a coding standard enforced by Black or any other formatter like Legato and LeTP does will be well-received by our team. SWIMDM-1759
Same comment above, The indentation is also off on line 72. It should be right under the ' on line 71. Same comments below.
Done - I re-read pep8 (been a while) and this is indeed following the optional recommendation for indentation.
